message_1: How many ways can you color the vertices of a given 5-vertex graph using only 3 colors, such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the chromatic polynomial. The chromatic polynomial P(G, k) of a graph G is a polynomial that counts the number of proper k-colorings of G (i.e., colorings of the vertices such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color).

For a complete graph with n vertices, the chromatic polynomial is given by:

P(K_n, k) = k(k-1)^{n-1} - k(k-1)(k-2)^{n-2}

In our case, we have a complete 5-vertex graph (K_5) and we want to color it using 3 colors (k=3). Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

P(K_5, 3) = 3(3-1)^{5-1} - 3(3-1)(3-2)^{5-2}
P(K_5, 3) = 3(2)^4 - 3(2)(1)^3
P(K_5, 3) = 3(16) - 3(2)
P(K_5, 3) = 48 - 6
P(K_5, 3) = 42

So, there are 42 ways to color the vertices of a given 5-vertex graph using only 3 colors such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color.
